conclusion: To determine if the two objects have the same acceleration at time \( t_1 \), we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
The graph shows the velocity \( v \) as a function of time \( t \) for two objects, A and B.
The slope of the velocity-time graph gives the acceleration. Specifically, the acceleration \( a \) is given by the derivative of the velocity with respect to time, \( a = \frac{dv}{dt} \).

conclusion: At time \( t_1 \), we need to find the slopes of the velocity-time graphs for objects A and B.
The slope of the graph at any point is the tangent to the curve at that point.

premise: The slope of the graph at any point is the tangent to the curve at that point.
conclusion: For object A, the tangent at \( t_1 \) is a straight line with a negative slope. This indicates that object A is decelerating.

premise: The slope of the graph at any point is the tangent to the curve at that point.
conclusion: For object B, the tangent at \( t_1 \) is also a straight line with a negative slope. This indicates that object B is decelerating as well.

premise: For object A, the tangent at \( t_1 \) is a straight line with a negative slope. For object B, the tangent at \( t_1 \) is also a straight line with a negative slope.
conclusion: By observing the slopes of the tangents at \( t_1 \) for both objects, we can see that the slopes are equal. This means that the accelerations of both objects are the same at \( t_1 \).

conclusion: The accelerations of the two objects are different at time \( t_1 \).
